msgSnippet: Tom Roche Wed Feb 11 2004 5:46 am ( fighting the anti-test-infection ) ... Tom Roche Fri 30 Apr 2004 16:12:43 -0400 ... Tom Roche Sunday, May 2, 2004, at
messageBody:
Tom Roche Wed Feb 11 2004 5:46 am ("fighting the anti-test-infection")
>>>>> IMHO the word needs to go out: test your @#$^%&* UIs, too!
>>>>> A thin UI is still good ... because it's easier to test.

Tom Roche Fri 30 Apr 2004 16:12:43 -0400
>>>> Not to mention more robust, more reusable, etc.

>>>>> But a well-designed, untested UI is just another hole in your
>>>>> coverage. </vent>

Tom Roche Sunday, May 2, 2004, at 9:15:01 AM
>>> it was at one time legitimate to say "I can't xUnit my UI, so I
>>> will try to do the best I can," i.e. create a thin UI
>>> well-separated from its model and control. But it was *never*
>>> legitimate to make a virtue of necessity, to say (as you do) that
>>> "separation is the solution." Now that you *can* drive your UIs
>>> from JUnit, and therefore you can *fully* test your UIs, your
>>> claim is illegitimate, and moreover encourages the
>>> "anti-test-infection."

Ron Jeffries Sun May 2, 2004 2:55 pm
>> I still don't have the necessary skill to do very well what Thomas
>> rightly recommends

Can you write a JUnit testcase? Then you can any of several j.a.R-
extending packages. Try it, it's easy. (Esp for Swing--Abbot's SWT
support is almost as good, and we're hoping to make it equivalent by
the end of the summer.)

J. B. Rainsberger Sun May 2, 2004 7:37 pm (rearranged)
> I hope that readers do not interpret your remark to mean that
> separation is ineffective.

See above.

> Separation is, however, a majority of the solution. It is easily 80%
> of the solution, if not more.

False. You are claiming that a properly designed UI need not be fully
tested. This is

* merely speculative: for all your design, if you haven't tested, you
don't know that it works. (I might add that the vast majority of
customers care much more that the code they've bought works as
specified than that it is well designed.)

* a bad practice that all-too-easily leads to worse practice (as
argued in "fighting the anti-test-infection" above)

* anachronistic: the tooling problems that formerly lent aid and
comfort to your view have been rectified.

I will go so far as to claim, ceteris paribus, better one's code be
thoroughly tested (presuming it passes those tests :-) than well
designed. (I will also claim that thorough testing promotes good
design, but that's because I'm a TDD true believer.)
